TEI:
Kalittokai 97.
itu “koṭiyōr koṭumai cuṭumeṉa ... pakutiyi ṉīṅkiya takutikkaṭ” ṭalaivi parattaiyarai yāṉaiyākak kūṟip pulantatu.
aṉṉai kaṭuñco laṟiyātāy pōlanī
yeṉṉaip pulappa toṟukkuveṉ maṉyāṉ
ciṟukālai yiṟkaṭai vantu kuṟiceyta
vavvaḻi yeṉṟumyāṉ kāṇēṉ ṟiritara
vevvaḻip paṭṭāy camaṉāka vivveḷḷal;
muttēr muṟuvalāy namvalaip paṭṭatōr
puttiyāṉai vantatu kāṇpāṉyāṉ ṟaṅkiṉēṉ;
okkum;
avviyāṉai vaṉappuṭait tākaluṅ kēṭṭēṉ;
avviyāṉaitāṉ, cuṇṇanī ṟāṭi naṟunaṟā nīruṇ
ṭoṇṇutal yātta tilaka vavirōṭait
toyyil poṟitta vaṉamulai vāṉkōṭṭut
toyyakat tōṭṭi kuḻaitāḻ vaṭimaṇi
yutti poṟitta puṉaipūṇ parumattu
muttēyk kumveṇ paṉṉakai tiṟantu
naṉṉakar vāyiṟ katava veḷilcārntut
taṉṉalaṅ kāṭṭit takaiyiṉāṟ kāṟaṭṭi vīḻkkun
toṭartoṭa rāka valantu paṭarceyyu
meṉṟōṭ ṭaṭakkaiyiṉ vāṅkit taṟkaṇṭār
nalaṅkavaḷaṅ koḷḷu nakaimuka vēḻattai
yiṉṟukaṇ ṭāypō levaṉemmaip poyppatunī;
ellā, keḻīit toṭiceṟitta tōḷiṇai tāṅkit
taḻīikkoṇ ṭūrntāyu nī;
kuḻīi, avāviṉāṟ ṟēmpuvā riṟkaṭai yāṟā
vuvāvaṇi yūrntāyu nī;
mikātu, cīrppaṭa vuṇṭa ciṟukaḷi yēruṇka
ṇīrkkuviṭ ṭūrntāyu nī;
cāarccār, neṟitā ḻiruṅkūnta ṉiṉpeṇṭi rellāñ
ciṟupāka rākac ciraṟṟātu mella
viṭāatu nīyemmil vantāyav viyāṉai
kaṭāam paṭumiṭat tōmpu.
“You are like that, as if you didn’t know harsh words.
I dislike [your] sulking with me.”
“Coming to the house gate in the early morning, I have never
seen that way in which marks are left [on you]. When you were about,
how did this ridiculous thing happen to you while nearby?”
“You with pearl-like teeth, I stayed on order to see
a new elephant come that had fallen into our net.”
“Typical.
I have heard that that elephant is beautiful, too.
That elephant, bathing in powdery dust, drinking water with fragrant toddy,
[its] shining [head] badge with a tilakam applied to the forehead,
with white tusks [that are] soft breasts imprinted with sandal paste,
the goad a head ornament, shapely gems hanging from the earrings,
decoration impressed on the head ornament, with an ornate waist-band/cushion,
a smile opening on white teeth that resemble pearls,
approaching the post at the entry gate of the good mansion,
the elephant bull with a smiling face that takes a rice ball of beauty
from those who see it, flexing [its] broad hand, the soft shoulders
that cause affliction when they become all chains,
which bring to fall by knocking [you] off [your] feet through loveliness, showing its/her beauty,
what [is the point] of you lying to us, as if you had seen [it] today?
Hey, you are the one who mounted, taking in an embrace
[and] enduring the arm pair with tight bracelets in union,
and you are the one who mounted the ornament [that is] a young lady/an elephant
while those who wither from longing are unappeased at the house gate, crowding,
and you are the one who mounted, leaving to the water
the beautiful kajal eyes [after] a little delight that was enjoyed excellently, without increasing.
You who have quietly come to our house,
without all your women with curly hanging dark tresses [who are] on all sides
being angry, as an under-mahout, without giving [them] up,
beware [the time] when that elephant undergoes rut.”
